Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper exclusion under s. 114(2) due to 'organized plan' and misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentations noted but humanitarian factors outweighed
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's jurisdictional error in applying rigid guidelines
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Holistic evaluation of humanitarian and compassionate factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Plaintiffs' establishment in Canada, family ties, and integration
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory discretion under s. 114(2) cannot be unduly restricted by guidelines
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Entitled to new hearing before different officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or visa documentation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Lawfulness of excluding applicants based on 'organized plan'
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of entry method and residency establishment
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Truthfulness of entry claims and integration in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Ministerial guidelines cannot override statutory discretion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Reliance on 'organized plan' exclusion in guidelines

Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiffs overstayed visas and applied under H&C program
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant past status, compliant present integration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Generally credible despite initial violations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper denial based on 'organized plan' and misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentation found but mitigated by humanitarian factors
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Establishment in Canada and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Jurisdictional error in rigid guideline application
Crimes.Application_Error: Denial based solely on 'organized plan' without H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Integration, employment, family ties in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory discretion prevails over restrictive guidelines
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior misrepresentation and mode of entry

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to depart after visa expiration
Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiffs remained beyond authorized stay and applied for permanent residency
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged participation in organized entry scheme
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible claimants despite immigration violations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Guidelines must not override statutory intent

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer followed proper procedure and applied guidelines fairly
Crimes.Governing_Law: De Facto Illegal Residents Program guidelines
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged misrepresentations were not properly assessed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Guidelines under the De Facto Illegal Residents Program
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to follow fair and humane assessment procedures
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of opportunity for applicant to respond
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider overall circumstances including economic and social establishment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of stay since 1981, social integration
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter or correctness depending on issue

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada after visa expiration
Crimes.Governing_Law: De Facto Illegal Residents Program guidelines
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa since 1981, applied under regularization program
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged but not substantiated with proper process
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No opportunity given to respond to allegations
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration manager to reject recommendation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documented reasoning for refusal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not adequately conducted
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of application and halt to deportation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to follow program guidelines and ensure fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of work permit and residency refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Fairness and adherence to immigration guidelines in refusal decision
Crimes.Governing_Law: De Facto Illegal Residents Program guidelines
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged misrepresentations not verified through fair process
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Improper rejection despite initial approval recommendation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of procedural fairness and failure to assess economic establishment
Crimes.Application_Error: Rejection without allowing response or full assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compliance with program guidelines and natural justice
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long-term presence and social ties in Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of application leading to legal challenge
Crimes.Authority: Department of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged false statements in application materials

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, case referred for redetermination
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Exclusion from refugee protection due to alleged involvement in crimes against humanity
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refugee Division raised exclusion issue during hearing
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Not assessed due to procedural breach
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Risk of persecution vs. exclusion for serious crimes
Crimes.Credibility: Not central to this procedural determination
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(a), Immigration Act s. 69.1(5) and s. 69(6)
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Serious international crime leading to exclusion
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Alleged individual involvement in crimes against humanity
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Civilian population, as per crimes against humanity

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Sufficiency of adjournment after mid-hearing issue introduction
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient time to prepare response to new issue
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to show procedural unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Counsel's representation of inability to prepare
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Reasonable opportunity to present case required
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of notice and inadequate preparation time
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing and nature of issue raising, duration of break
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Refugee Division proceeded with limited adjournment

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of right to procedural fairness through denial of adjournment
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Claimant's ability to respond to new issue
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of adequate time to prepare
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Counsel’s request and explanation of unpreparedness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Right to fair hearing under natural justice
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Mid-hearing introduction of Article 1F(a) without notice
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and timing of adjournment, complexity of issue
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Panel allowed 80-minute break instead of full adjournment
Crimes.Outcome: Application granted, matter referred for redetermination

Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's failure to seek asylum in the UK, voluntary returns to Turkey, speculative testimony, vague statements
Decision_Outcome: Rejection of credible basis for refugee claim
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credible basis
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in behavior and testimony, lack of explicit fear demonstration
Legal_Rule: Panel must provide clear and unmistakable reasons for rejecting a refugee claim based on credibility
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credible basis
Key_Evidence_Considered: Voluntary return to Turkey, lack of asylum-seeking in UK, vague and speculative testimony
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Governing_Law: United Nations Convention relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Application_Facts: Cuero was convicted of cocaine trafficking, a serious non-political crime. The Board focused on the nature of the crime, not post-conviction behavior like rehabilitation.
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee protection exclusion
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Exclusion under Article 1F(b) based on seriousness of prior conviction
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Rehabilitation is irrelevant under Article 1F(b); focus is on the nature of the crime at the time of commission
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board; Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether failure to consider rehabilitation constitutes procedural unfairness
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board; Federal Court
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board; Federal Court
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Nature of the crime determines seriousness; rehabilitation not relevant
Crimes.Legal_Framework: United Nations Convention relating to the Status of Refugees, Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: No breach found; Board applied correct legal standard

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to assess and document risk
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s 9.6(2) of the Act and s 71(1)(c) of the Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: The Applicant did not conduct a formal risk assessment despite being required to do so under the Act.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to develop a written ongoing compliance training program
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: s 96.1(1) of the Act and s 7(1)(d) of the Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal partially allowed, case returned for re-determination of penalties
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to establish a documented training program for employees and agents
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act and Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to develop and apply written compliance policies and procedures
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Non-compliance with mandatory compliance policy requirements
Crimes.Governing_Law: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-examination appeal before tribunal or court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Policies were inadequate and updates occurred after the examination period

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Systemic non-compliance with AML/CFT obligations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court upheld violations but remanded penalty determination due to lack of transparency

Governing_Law: Charter of Rights and Freedoms (implied principles)
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Colombia due to FARC threats after denouncing engineers to police; claimed persecution linked to political opinion
Procedural_Issue: Board misled applicants on nexus to Convention ground
Failed to provide fair opportunity to respond
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider key evidence
Decision_Outcome: Negative refugee determination by the Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Nexus to a Convention refugee ground
Decision_Rationale: Board's errors in applying procedural fairness and misinterpretation of evidence rendered decision unreasonable

Application_Facts: Applicant provided inconsistent evidence (194 vs. 33 days absent); lacked credible documentation
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application
Evidence_Used: Applicant's submitted residency records and declarations
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and consistent documentation
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found discrepancies and deemed evidence unreliable
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge’s determination was reasonable based on unreliable and inconsistent evidence

Dispute_Type: Breach of duty of care in providing commercial information
Legal_Issue: Whether government misrepresentation regarding employment conditions for fishing licenses constituted actionable misconduct
Governing_Law: Tort law, specifically duty of care in informational statements
Outcome: Nine plaintiffs awarded compensation of $53,000 each, reduced by $3,000 for those requiring new gear
Credibility_Assessment: Government statements were found to be misleading and relied upon by plaintiffs
Evidence_Type: Correspondence, government policies, testimonies from plaintiffs and officials
Legal_Provision: Duty of care under tort law when information is provided with foreseeability of reliance
Basis_of_Claim: Detrimental reliance on false government representations about license eligibility
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Plaintiffs sold fishing privileges based on belief they would lose eligibility due to outside employment
Application_Error: Government incorrectly communicated eligibility criteria for 1982 salmon fishing licenses
Assessment_Standard: Reasonable foreseeability of reliance on official statements
Legal_Standard: Existence of duty of care, misrepresentation, justifiable reliance, and resulting damages
Application_Factor: Plaintiffs' decision to sell fishing rights was directly influenced by government statements
Decision_Outcome: Compensation awarded to nine plaintiffs for financial losses
Authority: Common law tort principles on negligent misrepresentation

Application_Facts: Applicant withdrew refugee claim based on advice; later sought reinstatement after new threats emerged.
Procedural_Issue: Withdrawal of claim; request for reinstatement under Rule 53
Evidence_Used: Evidence of new threats after withdrawal
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to demonstrate how reinstatement was in the interests of justice
Decision_Rationale: No breach of natural justice or substantial defect; applicant did not show reinstatement was in the interests of justice

Application_Facts: ADIR seeks to amend pleadings arguing subclasses are patentably distinct; Schering and Hoechst oppose, citing irrelevance and lack of detrimental reliance.
Decision_Outcome: Motion to amend pleadings is allowed
Outcome: Amended pleadings permitted to proceed to trial
Remedy_Sought: Inclusion of argument on patentable distinctness of subclasses
Legal_Standard_Applied: Amendments should only be denied in plain and obvious cases
Decision_Rationale: Amendment does not prejudice other parties and raises valid issues for trial

Legal_Issue: Did the Minister breach the duty of procedural fairness in revoking the applicant's security clearance?
Outcome: The decision to revoke the security clearance is quashed, and the matter is remitted for re-determination.
Basis_of_Claim: Revocation based on undisclosed allegations of association with a drug smuggling ring
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient disclosure of allegations and lack of opportunity to respond
Application_Error: Failure to disclose key information such as identity of Subject A and details of association
Evidence_Ignored: Details from RCMP reports, identity of Subject A
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires adequate disclosure and opportunity to respond
Application_Factor: Revocation of existing security clearance triggers higher procedural fairness obligations
Authority: Minister under Section 4.8 of the Aeronautics Act

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Insufficient disclosure of allegations and identity of Subject A
Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Withheld key information including specifics of association and identity of Subject A
Criminal_Activity: Association with a drug importation ring
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; decision overturned
Basis_for_Decision: Undisclosed allegations of association with drug importation ring
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Yes – failure to provide sufficient details to allow meaningful response

Violation_Type: Revocation of security clearance without proper procedure
Application_Facts: Applicant not given details about allegations involving Subject A or source of information
Procedural_Issue: Lack of transparency and intelligibility in decision-making process
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Withholding of key identifying and contextual details
Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed and remitted for re-determination
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient disclosure hindered ability to respond meaningfully

Legal_Issue: Did the Minister breach procedural fairness by failing to disclose sufficient information?
Evidence_Assessment: Key details from RCMP reports not disclosed
Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed and remitted for re-determination
Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of information used in decision-making
Grounds_for_Claim: Undisclosed allegations of association with drug smuggling ring
Legal_Framework: Aeronautics Act and administrative law principles
Authority: Minister under Section 4.8 of the Aeronautics Act

Application_Facts: Applicant studied in Canada for four years; visa officer assumed strong ties to Canada without allowing applicant to respond to concerns about intent to leave
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with temporary status during studies
Procedural_Issue: Lack of opportunity to address concerns about intent to return to Colombia
Evidence_Used: Duration of study in Canada as indicator of weakened ties to home country
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider applicant's evidence of ties to Colombia; reliance on generalization
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; decision based on assumptions rather than credibility findings
Decision_Outcome: Application refused based on presumed inability to leave Canada
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different visa officer
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer relied on stereotype that prolonged stay in Canada severs foreign ties, without giving applicant chance to respond
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office

Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence linking general conditions in Haiti to personal situation
Legal_Provision: s. 25, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Credibility_Factor: Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence
Legal_Rule: s. 25 IRPA – humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Convictions for multiple crimes including drug trafficking and assault
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of personalized risk evidence regarding Haiti
Decision_Rationale: No unusual or disproportionate hardship established

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of Narcotics for the Purpose of Trafficking
Risk_Nexus: No direct personal risk established despite health and family ties
Basis_for_Decision: Lack of unusual or disproportionate hardship

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal on H&C grounds
Evidence_Assessment: All factors considered but no undue hardship found
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show exceptional circumstances

Basis_for_Decision: No unusual or disproportionate hardship proven

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of denial of H&C application
Evidence_Assessment: Factors considered but insufficient to establish hardship

Credibility_Assessment: Found to lack credibility by the Board

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding gang-related activities
Legal_Rule: Inadmissible if engaged in organized criminal activity with multiple persons

Prior_Criminality: Conviction for assault causing bodily harm
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence found by the Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of weapons for dangerous purposes
Legal_Issue: Whether sufficient evidence supported gang-related activity finding
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence included weapons possession and gang links
Legal_Rule: Inadmissible if part of organized criminal pattern

Violation_Type: Failure to rebut presumption of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 97(1)
Governing_Law: Charter of Rights and Freedoms (indirectly applicable)
Application_Facts: Antonio Leon Davila claimed persecution in Mexico; did not file formal charges; attempted informal means to seek protection
Residency_Compliance: Claimant sought protection in Canada; status pending at time of review
Procedural_Issue: Insufficient analysis by the original Board; lack of thorough assessment of state protection efforts
Evidence_Used: Claimant's testimony, attempts to seek help in Mexico, country condition reports
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide clear and convincing evidence that Mexican authorities were unable or unwilling to protect
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on sufficiency of evidence and legal application
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a differently constituted Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Claimant must provide clear and convincing evidence that state is unable or unwilling to protect
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to adequately analyze whether Mexico’s democratic institutions translated into effective protection; insufficient reasoning on state protection issue
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the refusal of security clearance was based on irrelevant considerations and whether procedural fairness was breached
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 509(c) of the Marine Transportation Security Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's criminal record and continued marijuana use were assessed as relevant to subornment risk
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unreasonableness or breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's ongoing marijuana use and criminal history affected credibility regarding security risk
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Refusal allowed if reasonable grounds to suspect applicant may be suborned to endanger marine transportation security
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged irrelevance of marijuana use and lack of adequate notice or reasons
Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal record including obstructing a peace officer
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister argued that drug use and criminal history posed a legitimate security concern
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of security clearance denial

Crimes.Crime_Name: Dangerous operation of a motor vehicle
Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Traffic-related offense with potential for harm
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Individual with criminal history and substance use
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high due to repeated offenses and substance involvement
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk of subornment in sensitive security environment
Crimes.Risk_Type: Security vulnerability due to potential coercion
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Not applicable – general threat to marine transportation security
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support reasonable suspicion under regulatory standard
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal record, admissions of drug use
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Deemed credible and relevant by reviewing body
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's history undermined trustworthiness for security clearance
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – administrative, not criminal sentencing

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had recent drug conviction and continued marijuana use
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of notice and reasons in denial process
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal regulatory authority over marine security clearances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about reliability due to illegal drug activity
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Minister’s decision upheld
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and reinstatement of application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds to suspect subornment risk
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Drug production and use indicate susceptibility to coercion in security-sensitive context

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of property obtained by crime under $1000
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative appeal of security clearance denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether denial was based on reasonable grounds and met procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 509(c) of the Marine Transportation Security Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Criminal history and drug use evaluated as indicators of subornment risk
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness or unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Pattern of criminal behavior and ongoing drug use reduced credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Clearance may be denied if reasonable grounds exist to suspect subornment risk
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that marijuana use was irrelevant and insufficient reasons provided
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction for possession of stolen property
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister emphasized legislative purpose of preventing security threats

Legal_Issue: Exclusion from refugee status under Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Governing_Law: Article 1E of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ability to return to and receive protection from Germany
Application_Factor: No risk of deportation from Germany
Authority: United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees

Dispute_Type: Alleged discriminatory funding practices by INAC against larger First Nations
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission's decision to investigate a complaint of discrimination based on national or ethnic origin is reasonable
Governing_Law: Section 5(b) and Section 41(1)(c) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: Not plain and obvious that the complaint fell outside the Commission's jurisdiction
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision to investigate was reasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the respondents to show the complaint is outside jurisdiction
Legal_Rule: Section 5(b) prohibits adverse differentiation based on prohibited grounds including national or ethnic origin; Section 41(1)(c) allows dismissal if outside jurisdiction
Grounds_for_Claim: Funding formulas disadvantaging larger First Nations due to size, alleged as discrimination based on national or ethnic origin
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; case concerned only the decision to investigate
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of funding formulas and their impact on larger First Nations
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act, Federal Courts Act
Defendant_Response: Size is not a prohibited ground; no link between funding and national origin
Evidence_Type: Policy documents, funding formulas, legal arguments
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission's decision to investigate
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: Section 5(b), Section 41(1)(c) of the Canadian Human Rights Act; Section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration violation under paragraph 27(2)(h) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Removal in conflict with judicial order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was removed despite a court order requiring his presence for a criminal hearing.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Removal executed without regard to conflicting judicial order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 50(1) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removal violated s. 50(1) as it conflicted with a judicial order requiring the applicant’s presence.

Crimes.Violation_Type: Execution of removal order conflicting with judicial requirement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant removed despite court order requiring attendance at criminal proceeding; later returned voluntarily.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to comply with s. 50(1) before removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Judicial order mandating presence for criminal hearing
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Declaration addressing consequences of unlawful removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Compliance with s. 50(1) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removal contravened statutory prohibition under s. 50(1); declaration warranted despite voluntary return.

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Lawfulness of removal during pending criminal proceedings
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Removal without ensuring compliance with judicial requirements
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Violation of s. 50(1) due to conflict with judicial order
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to ensure presence required by court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to analyze subjective fear of persecution before assessing state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted by tribunal

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Subjective fear analysis required prior to state protection evaluation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to assess subjective fear before determining state protection availability
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Lack of credibility analysis regarding fear of persecution

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Threats from FARC not assessed for credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subjective fear must be evaluated before state protection

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative tribunal decision under review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay in the U.S. and illegal entry into Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to seek asylum in the United States

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant suspected of PKK membership based on undisclosed evidence; requested disclosure but received no response.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to inadmissibility concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of meaningful disclosure of grounds and evidence prior to interview
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose key evidence affecting decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant denied fair opportunity to respond to allegations due to non-disclosure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Procedural fairness breach in immigration process
Crimes.Violation_Type: Breach of procedural fairness in assessing inadmissibility
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Pusat not informed of specific reasons for suspicion of PKK membership despite repeated requests; no post-interview submission allowed
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Mr. Pusat, applicant for permanent residency
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose grounds and evidence, denial of opportunity to respond
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Denial of procedural fairness undermined legitimacy of decision-making process

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Suspected membership in PKK, a designated terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with terrorist group
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Reasonable grounds to believe applicant was a member of PKK

Crimes.Crime_Name: Excessive use of force by peace officer
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Civil rights violation, excessive force claim
Crimes.Outcome: Action dismissed; no excessive force found
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged physical harm during cell extraction, including multiple strikes and partial undressing
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Plaintiff failed to prove excessive force or causation of injury
Crimes.Protected_Group: Prisoners (as a vulnerable group under state care)
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Officers acted within legal authority; state protection deemed adequate
Crimes.Credibility: Conflicting witness testimonies; medical evidence inconclusive
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s.25 Criminal Code (use of force by peace officers)
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Found adequate; actions justified under law
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Use of physical force in custodial setting

Crimes.Crime_Name: Cruel and unusual treatment under Charter s.12
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether strip cell confinement amounted to cruel and unusual punishment
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 12 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Trial stage with full evidentiary hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff refused showers and exercise; conditions not shown to be degrading
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No violation of s.12 Charter rights
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to show treatment outraged standards of decency
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff's own behavior limited impact of deprivation claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Treatment must outrage standards of decency to breach s.12
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Prolonged strip cell confinement without normal privileges
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Witness testimony, medical reports, inmate behavior logs
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Confinement justified for safety and security

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Duration of confinement (two and a half months), lack of hygiene products
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Behavioral concerns justifying monitoring, refusal of privileges by inmate
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to prolonged isolation
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Administrative segregation without formal justification argued
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient – issue not raised in argument
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff’s claim not fully tested due to lack of argument
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – civil case, no conviction
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Common law tort of false imprisonment

Crimes.Location_of_Incident: Inside prison cell at Saskatchewan Penitentiary
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of force during cell extraction, allegations of repeated striking
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Plaintiff resisted, force applied in controlled environment
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not relevant – focus on state actor conduct
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Medium – alleged physical harm but unproven
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Medical evidence did not confirm injury causation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff's account contradicted by official records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, s.25 Criminal Code

Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Extortion, threats, retaliation by MS gang
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Personalized risk due to reporting gang activity

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Retaliation for reporting gang, witness to murder
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Positive
Accepted by Board

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Killing intended as warning to applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent with testimony
Accepted by Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Participation in activities of criminal organization

Violation_Type: Security risk related to civil aviation
Application_Facts: Fontaine associated with criminal organization, failed to refute
Credibility_Assessment: Failure to refute allegations viewed as lack of credibility
Decision_Rationale: Association raised legitimate concerns about aviation security

Nature_of_Acts: Threats from FARC due to a money laundering account dispute
Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to prove inadequate state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Evidence accepted but insufficient to meet legal test
Standard_of_Proof: Claimants must prove inability or futility in seeking state protection

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on risk from non-state actors
Consequences_of_Action: Threats leading to flight from Colombia

Crimes.Crime_Name: Corruption of Judicial or Public Officials
Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving threats due to corruption-related banking issue

Evidence_Assessment: Board focused on general country conditions rather than individual targeting
Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to show futility of seeking state protection
Credibility_Factor: Applicants did not seek police protection
Legal_Rule: State protection requires proof of inadequacy or futility
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal test, reasonableness for factual application
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC due to banking dispute

Sub_Crime_Type: Death threats by armed non-state actor
Aggravating_Factors: Specific targeting due to financial dispute
Prior_Criminality: FARC’s history of violence and extortion
Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat from organized armed group
Risk_Assessment: Serious personal risk upon return to Colombia
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – specific threats due to bank account issue
Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence accepted but legal test misapplied
Credibility_Assessment: Consistent and truthful, but burden not met

Aggravating_Factors: Use of threats to extract compliance
Criminality_Severity: High – systemic criminal behavior by armed group
Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm if returned
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – direct threats over financial matter
Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged, but protection analysis flawed
Legal_Provision: IRPA, s. 96 - Definition of Convention refugee

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim arising from involvement in money laundering scheme
Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection for those threatened over financial crimes
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim denial
Evidence_Assessment: Board relied on general security improvements
Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to show state cannot provide protection
Credibility_Factor: Relied on advice from army officer not to report
Legal_Rule: State protection must be assessed for specific individuals
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of FARC retaliation over money laundering account
Legal_Framework: Refugee determination process under Canadian law

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Foreseeable risk of violence after verbal altercation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reliable based on officer documentation and procedural gaps

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Duty of Care under Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether CSC breached its duty of care to ensure inmate safety

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to act on pre-indicators of violence and inadequate security
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CSC argued no breach occurred

State_Protection_Adequacy: Investigation met standards of fairness and thoroughness

Victim_Basis: Employment discrimination based on prohibited grounds under CHRA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 44(1) and (2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was convicted of drug trafficking, leading to an admissibility report; Officers Cobb and Ho acted within their limited discretion
Procedural_Issue: Whether procedural fairness required informing the applicant or allowing submissions before referral
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found
Decision_Rationale: Officers are not required under s. 44(1) or (2) to inform applicants or accept submissions prior to preparing a report or referring it for a hearing

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Legal_Provision_Involved: s. 44(1), s. 44(2), and s. 36(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to inform applicant about s. 44(1) report and referral, and not allowing written submissions
Evidence_Disclosure_Status: No disclosure of report or opportunity for submissions prior to decision
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred
Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug trafficking with a four-year sentence
Basis_for_Decision: Conviction details and statutory authority under IRPA
